subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 5, Lambas and Fundamentals
msgSnippet: ... OK, that is quite nice. You have  specific annotations and you can give them string names to use as a reference as well for running. [Non-text portions of
messageBody:
On 24 January 2013 11:59, Dawid Weiss <dawid.weiss@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> > For the first two, you would achieve the same if you just declare your
> > category names as String constants and reference those, while giving the
> > option to write typos if you prefer. I don't quite understand the third
> > bullet so I don't know about that.
> >
>
> The third bullet is related to the first two. The @Slow annotation is
> declared as:
>
> @Documented
> @Inherited
> @Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
> @TestGroup(enabled = true, sysProperty = "slow")
> public @interface Slow {}
>
> the @TestGroup indicates @Slow is a category, it is enabled by default and
> it can be turned on or off with a -Dslow=[on,off,true,false,yes,no] system
> property, regardless of how this property is passed to the runner (IDE,
> command line, etc.).
>
>
OK, that is quite nice. You have specific annotations and you can give
them string names to use as a reference as well for running.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
